awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Integrated Development of Bioenergy Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Nebraska, located in Lincoln, Nebraska, will support the training for 10 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2021- 2023. The program focuses on bioenergy -- the application of molecular and physiologic principles using microbes, algae and plants to create renewable sources of energy to promote a sustainable society. It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities or from an under-represented group, will be trained in the program. One of the greatest challenges facing 21st-century society is finding a sustainable energy supply. Energy is the basis for a large portion of the global economy and, currently, is largely dependent on nonrenewable fossil fuels that contribute significantly to pollution and climate change. This REU project will train students in finding solutions to overcome this challenge. 

Faculty from the School of Biological Sciences, the Center for Plant Science Innovation and other departments will serve as mentors. Diverse and exciting student projects can employ molecular biology, biochemistry and/or genetics to understand energy dynamics in model species. Students are expected to do full-time laboratory research as well as to participate in seminars and various workshops about ethics in research, professionalism, career opportunities in industry and academia, and the graduate school application process. Students will present the results of their work at scientific conferences, tour energy industries and undergo training in technical writing using a student-centered approach. Students are selected based on academic record, research performance, and potential for outstanding research. Assessment will be done using the SALG URSSA online tool to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked to determine their career advancement. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.unl.edu/summerprogram/research#bioenergy, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Paul Blum at pblum1@unl.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Heriberto Cerutti at hcerutti1@unl.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Integrated Development of Bioenergy Systems at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) brought together a diverse team of microbiologists and plant biologists to provide undergraduates with immersive, hands-on research experiences. The program's core objectives were to engage students in active learning and to inspire them to pursue careers in scientific research that addresses critical societal needs.

Addressing 21st-Century Energy/Biomaterials Demands

One of the most pressing challenges of the 21st century is ensuring a sustainable energy future. The global economy relies heavily on energy, yet the current dependence on finite, nonrenewable fossil fuels is unsustainable. In contrast, biomass derived from plants, algae, and cyanobacteria offers a renewable, carbon-neutral alternative for producing energy and biomaterials. Moreover, microbes offer efficient and sustainable ways to convert this biomass into liquid fuels or chemical feedstock. With adequate research and proper implementation, biological systems -ranging from plants to microbes- hold significant promise for addressing global energy and biomaterials needs. However, realizing this potential requires a new generation of scientists trained in interdisciplinary research.

Program Structure and Training

Leveraging the expertise of faculty from the Microbiology Initiative (MBI) and the Center for Plant Science Innovation (CPSI), the REU fostered collaborative, cross-disciplinary research and training with a focus on innovative bioenergy solutions. Key program components included:

  • Hands-on research: 30 students from diverse backgrounds engaged in 10-week laboratory projects, ranging from microbial biofuel conversion to algal/plant biomass optimization.
  • Professional development: Workshops on research ethics, lab safety, professional conduct, and STEM career pathways complemented technical training.
  • Scientific communication: Weekly discussions and literature reviews honed critical thinking, while a concluding symposium enabled students to present their findings to peers, mentors, and the general public.

Outcomes and Impact

Beyond equipping participants with technical and analytical skills, the program fostered scientific identity and public engagement capabilities. Through close mentorship and active participation in research, students developed foundational scientific skills, gained exposure to current challenges in renewable energy, and improved their ability to analyze and communicate complex topics within the field. The REU's emphasis on communication training further empowered participants to articulate the societal significance of bioenergy research, bridging the gap between science and public understanding.
